page.title: 08ST RADIGUNDS ABBEY-HISTORY
page.content: Richard I granted Bradsole manor to the canons of St.Radigunds for the establishment of a monastry.Building began in 1191,continuing for 50 years. Site problems were encountered, the bleak position made it bitterly cold in winter and rough woodland tracks were frequently impassable. The Abbey became richly endowed with rights over Alkham,River,Capel and Postling churches and other large areas.During the late 13th century increasingly secular activities were undertaken,the monks acting as King's representatives who superintended defence work at Dover Castle.15th century neglect led to crumbling buildings and by 1491 only 8 canons remained.The early 16th century saw renovation of the main buildings.The monastry was dissolved in 1538.The stone was used to build Sandgate Castle.
